They've discovered the state of matter that cats are!

Literally all that is happening is that at a given temperature that structure is more stable, but as you increase the temp the chains are liquified due to weaker bonding and being higher energy.
It's like putting a carbon atom inside a buckyball, the lone carbon is the highest in energy due to less bonding, so when you heat it up the lone carbon will vaporize/melt first. Does that mean carbon has a solid-liquid phase? No, absolutely not because all that is occurring is the degradation of the structure, not a new state of matter.
Besides, any reasonable definition for a state of matter can be applied to a single atom/molecule, this can't. (Not to mention that chemical potential very clearly says the claim in nonsense.)
